results.content: This is an intermediate course and really requires a good knowledge of Vue & Node beforehand. In your own code you will run into issues due to package versions, and you will need to troubleshoot them by yourself. It is very fast paced and is great as a refresher or to understand how all these components works together to form an coherent application. Definitely worth the time spent.
results.content_html: This is an intermediate course and really requires a good knowledge of Vue & Node beforehand. In your own code you will run into issues due to package versions, and you will need to troubleshoot them by yourself. It is very fast paced and is great as a refresher or to understand how all these components works together to form an coherent application. Definitely worth the time spent.

results.content:
This is a good course for experienced developers that want to see how to connect the backend & frontend together using the MEVN stack. 

I already had a basic knowledge of Node, Express & advanced knowledge of JavaScript & Vue's ecosystem(Vue router, Vuex, Vue CLI). Therefore, I was able to connect the dots & see the bigger picture of using the MEVN stack quickly which is exactly what I was looking for.

However, I can't recommend this course to a beginner developer or a developer that doesn't have some knowledge of the MEVN stack individually since there is no explanation whatsoever on each individual topic.
results.content_html:
This is a good course for experienced developers that want to see how to connect the backend & frontend together using the MEVN stack.

I already had a basic knowledge of Node, Express & advanced knowledge of JavaScript & Vue's ecosystem(Vue router, Vuex, Vue CLI). Therefore, I was able to connect the dots & see the bigger picture of using the MEVN stack quickly which is exactly what I was looking for.

However, I can't recommend this course to a beginner developer or a developer that doesn't have some knowledge of the MEVN stack individually since there is no explanation whatsoever on each individual topic.

results.content:
Final review upon finishing: If you want to see how Vue, Express, Mongo, and Node all connect together to make an app, this is a decent place to start if you are willing to work through some bugs and figure out a lot of stuff on your own.  The course moves very quickly.  David is coding pretty much constantly.  As he does so, he describes very briefly what he is doing.  The problem is that he only infrequently says WHY he is doing it.  That part is mostly left for you to figure out.  And the bigger picture perspectives about how things work together are also, for the most part, left for you to figure out.

So this course has a good base of content, I think, but could be a lot better with some more information, so all in all, a bit of a missed opportunity. With just a bit more effort could have been a much more effective course.
results.content_html:

The course moves very quickly. David is coding pretty much constantly. As he does so, he describes very briefly what he is doing. The problem is that he only infrequently says WHY he is doing it. That part is mostly left for you to figure out. And the bigger picture perspectives about how things work together are also, for the most part, left for you to figure out.

So this course has a good base of content, I think, but could be a lot better with some more information, so all in all, a bit of a missed opportunity. With just a bit more effort could have been a much more effective course.

results.content:
I feel that that content covered is good and I learned a lot.  I would highly recommend this tutorial to anyone who has worked with Vue.js a little before and if a beginner to Vue.js then I would recommend reading the docs as you go.

Liked:
* The style and layout of the files.  
* The clean code.
* The direct approach, for the most part.

Disliked:
* No time to keep up, had to rewind a lot.
* A few syntax errors that should have been caught post-production of the video with added popup bubbles addressing them.
* Misspoke a few times leading to a little confusion.

TIP: 
For Section 4-18 @ 3:50 minutes
If using Windows, in the package.json file when setting the node_env variable , there cannot be any spaces between the word production (or development) and the two ampersands (&&), otherwise the space becomes part of the string.  
Found out the hard way.  :(
Exp...
"build": "set NODE_ENV=production&& babel dev-server... " 

Confirmed here...
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25112510/how-to-set-environment-variables-from-within-package-json-node-js

results.content:
so so. A lot is covered, and he is clearly proficient. But there is little orientation or context.  just mechanically walks through the steps without giving much why. Giving the benefit of the doubt, one could argue that he assumes someone has already worked with the MEAN or MERN stack, and just needs the differences between that and MEVN.  But it is a little disorienting for someone whose first modern stack is MEVN. 

Also, posted a couple of questions due to the fact that the videos have become slightly outdated/out of synch with the current file structure that gets built by vue-cli, and have gone weeks without a response.

results.content: Good course, I like the way the code is created and tested. However, you need to pause and rewind a lot. Also, there are many explanations omitted with the time available so you need more than a basic understanding of Javacript to follow the videos.

results.content: Course is way too fast specially on important topics. Content is great, but the speed of concepts and code explanation makes a simple class stressing.
